“Creative people engage in creative activities regularly. They organize their lives to enable them to practice their art or craft or skill. They safeguard their solitary time. Waiting depletes creative energy; creating increases creative energy.” — Louise Desalvo

Each month I provide #writingthelayers prompts that are meant to spark an idea or train of thought that gets you writing. When you read the prompt, what memories, images, feelings, or impulses come to mind? Using these prompts as writing triggers, you can explore your voice and creative impulses in a playful, no stress way. If you decide to share your writings, please use the hashtag so we can find you. 

Not comfortable sharing your words yet, but also feeling the urge to? One way to deal with this is to create an anonymous IG page for your writing so you can experience what it’s like to share that way and then just see what happens. It’s ok to build courage in your own way. 

If you like writing in community, you can join us this Friday, December 2 at 7 pm et for my free monthly writing workshop (link in bio) where we'll be writing from this list.  New faces are always welcome.

The Imagine & Grow Creative Exploration workbook features prompts from the #writingthelayers monthly series, plus reflection and affirmation prompts. This workbook is a mini-workshop that you can do as a self-study, with a friend, or a group. You can use the prompts for journal entries, writing and drawing challenges, storytelling circles, idea generation and brainstorming.

Remember, creative exploration is an authentic need that supports overall wellness & a fully expressed life. ✨

We have to stop fearing fear. When we realize that we’re going to experience fear one way or another, we can begin to make conscious choices about how we respond to it. 

Your creative courage expands when you become intimate with your fear. Instead of a heavy, opaque, impossible force, fear can become a guidance system. Likewise, knowing your values gives you courage to make decisions that keep you in alignment with your inner power, even if you feel fear while doing it. Instead of fleeting feel-good moments, your values can provide you with long-term fulfillment. 

Here’s a condensed example of what I came up with when I did the exercise explained in the video. 

Goal:  getting a book deal for my work-in-progress
Fear:  both failure & success, criticism, disappointing others, expectations that follow, etc.
Values:  the process is more valuable than the product, helping even one person with my story is enough, this is my calling

This exercise helps you identify and name your specific fears, as well as your specific values, so you can see through the fog of mixed emotions and find a mental pathway to creative courage. 

Will you be trying this exercise?

If I could share any advice with myself when I started my creative journey, it would be to learn how to separate my worth from the results of my work and to develop self-care habits that would sustain me through the emotional challenges of the creative life. My Creative Courage Writing Intensive is a 6-week series that provides clear concepts and hands-on practice to show you the patterns of behavior that lead to greater courage and fuller expression.  Early bird registration opens on Monday, 12/5. Link in bio to learn more.

I started the Reclaim Creative Coaching Program to provide creatives and purpose-seekers with the guidance and community they need to start, reactivate, or make progress on a creative project while establishing a life-long creative practice.

The Creative Courage Writing Intensive is the foundational framework of the program. The purpose is to provide detailed guidance on recognizing the creative process at play in your lives, and developing the discernment, mindset and habits that light the path to fuller expression.

Creative courage is not just about artistic projects, it’s about keeping our minds flexible for the challenges we face in life and work. It’s knowing that all the dreams we have for our lives require vision and imagination: If you want to change careers or get a promotion. Change your eating habits. Start a passion project. Move across the world. Grow a garden. Build a house. It doesn’t matter— creative courage is about trusting your instincts, tuning into your values, and reclaiming your story.

Do you have a creative calling or goal that you can’t seem to start, continue, or finish? What I find again and again is that many of us leave the emotional and energetic dynamics out of our practical plans. We set goals with our minds and not our hearts, and then we wonder why we run out of steam. We become fixated on results, and overlook the wins that live in the process. Sometimes we just need to refresh the way we look at things.

This workshop is ideal for those who value creative expression, but struggle to overcome doubt, self-consciousness, and uncertainty. At the end of the workshop, participants will have the opportunity to share their story project during a public showcase on Zoom.

You can see all the details and register through the link in my bio. To preview one of the exercises from the course, download the Value Statement Exercise. The early bird period ends on 12/16.

Our areas of difference are pathways to our creative genius. But too often our areas of difference become a source of pain when they are not valued. Your difference might be a struggle, hardship, or limitation. Your difference might be a unique interest, passion, or gift. Your inner critic has the worst kind of imagination and it offers up all the worst interpretations of who you are. These #journalingwithGG exercises help you develop your inner coach, a source of imagination for what else is possible. 

By writing down what’s on your mind, you can discover the ability to reshape narratives that don’t serve you, and with this awareness you can uncover new mental pathways and storylines for your life. I offer many resources for this work through:

— my free community that meets on the first friday of each month to write, release, and heal.
— my monthly subscription called The Inner Story that includes weekly pep talks, weekly cowriting sessions, and monthly workshops to keep you writing consistently. 
— I also offer a range of self-discovery and storytelling workshops that will rejuvenate your creative mindset and provide new entry points to writing and fuller expression. 

You can learn more at allthemanylayers.com or link in bio.

Assumptions are barriers to creative thinking and block us from visualizing new possibilities. What assumptions are you making that could be keeping your creative callings out of reach?

Creative courage is all about questioning your assumptions and showing yourself what’s possible when you take inspired action in spite of old assumptions. When you’re an intentional creator, you know that resistance is part of the creative process, and you can come to understand it instead of fighting with it. 

The Creative Courage Writing Intensive offers detailed guidance on how to recognize the creative process at play in your life, how to capture your unique life material through writing, and how to develop the discernment, mindset and habits that sustain you as you face the emotional challenges of the creative life. 

This 6-week experience is ideal for those who crave creative expression, but are struggling to overcome fears of vulnerability, commitment, and uncertainty. During the course of the workshop, writers learn a 4-step process for developing ideas and bringing them to life; and how to develop a unique arsenal of techniques, exercises and habits that support creative resilience and expansion.

Do you have a creative calling or goal that you can’t seem to start, continue, or finish? You can learn more about Creative Courage through the link in my bio. And you can access one of the key practices from the series by watching the Values in Action video and doing the exercise. Early Bird Registration ends this Friday, December 16. ✨

The biggest takeaway here is that your pace is an expression of your authenticity, and you will thrive when you are true to yourself. The life you want, the life that feels good to you, doesn’t have to make sense to anyone else. 

Overwhelm from trying to rush, force, and push will make your creative callings feel out of reach. But when you learn that there is a natural process at play, and what it feels like to give yourself what you need, old restrictions slowly fade. Your emotional needs are being met, so you have more energy. Your spiritual needs are being met, so you have more faith. Your creative needs are being met, so you feel more inspired. 

Once I realized that I could ease my anxiety and overwhelm + slow down without everything falling apart, I discovered that the slow down didn’t have to be a temporary thing just for healing. Slow could be my unapologetic normal. Slow could be how I live, create, run my business, everything— and without sacrificing opportunity or abundance. When I stopped being driven by a need to prove myself, and learned how to fuel my creative process through self-care, I found clarity, focus, and renewed energy. 

I’ve packaged a foundational framework to bring this clarity to other heart-centered creatives who struggle with creative blocks and limiting beliefs. Today is the last day of early bird registration for the winter session of my Creative Courage Writing Intensive. If you want to take the stress out of your ambitions, make progress on your creative goals, and learn strategies for long-term creative abundance, you should consider joining us. You can visit the link in my bio to learn more about Creative Courage and my other Reclaim Group Coaching offerings.

Sending love and peace to everyone 🙏🏾

Many writers and creatives who come to me have secret, suppressed, or hidden creative callings. They don’t tell anyone that they write or make up stories. Or maybe they stopped telling people because they haven’t found the right people to tell. Many have jobs and lives where their creativity is stifled or even openly dismissed. And then there are the secret writers who are already writers, working in roles that involve words and narrative but not the vulnerable, creative expression they crave. 

I spent my corporate years in a company that developed me from a raw college graduate to a seasoned professional, but no matter how much I learned and thrived there, I never felt inspired on a soul level. Eventually I learned that this deeper level of connection, for me, would be an essential part of my fulfillment as a human being and that I’d never feel satisfied at even the most wonderful company making the most wonderful money if my soul was not involved.

If you feel like you are lacking meaning, inspiration and fulfillment in your current roles and responsibilities, you have the choice to return to your creative roots (we all have them) and bring that part of your life back into focus. When I started blogging as a creative outlet/side hustle while working my day job, I felt a dormant part of me come alive and I felt hope that I’d been missing for a long time. What I didn’t know then that I know now is that rediscovering that creative energy inside was the easy part. The hard part would be learning how to nurture it because my nervous system + behavioral patterns were all wired against it. My ego was in control, I didn’t know what my authentic needs were, and I got my motivation from validation and approval. There was emotional work I had to do to stop blocking and resisting my authentic power and my gifts. 

From January 1 - January 7, I’m hosting a Creative Courage New Year Challenge where I’ll be sharing seven exercises to overcome creative fears through self-discovery. The challenge will take place on my @writingthelayers page. Tag a friend below who needs to be a part of this challenge. ✨

Scarcity thinking hinders creativity. One of the first things I learned when I committed to unlearning scarcity is that when you feel stuck or lacking in one area of your life, you can tap into the abundance that you have in another area of your life to find the feeling of overflow and supply. Scarcity is the dominant narrative in our culture, so this unlearning can be awkward, confusing, and isolating at first.

One way that shows up in a practical way in the life of a creative is when you are trying to get out of the feast/famine cycle when it comes to clients, jobs, money, ideas, energy, etc. It’s hard not to focus on the feeling of lack when there is evidence of it in your reality, but when you’re a creative thinker with an abundance mindset, you know there is an invisible supply of resources that’s beyond your immediate sight. Gratitude opens our eyes and makes us more open and receptive to all forms of abundance.

We narrow our vision when we only look for abundance in the form that we expect: money, a fully formed idea, immediate erasure of a problem. Abundance is an inner experience before it’s an outer experience.

It might show up as a juicy, but not fully formed idea. It might show up as a stepping stone that leads to an opportunity. It might show up in the form of an unexpected teacher/lesson that we need in order to unlock some next level. So how can writing foster abundance and a more creative mindset?

This fall, I posted weekly reels sharing exercises that help with this. I put together a writing guide with eleven of those exercises for my AML newsletter subscribers. You’re welcome to download it through the link in my bio. If you’re already a subscriber, check your inbox. 🎁

Creatives, 

If you have creative dreams and goals but struggle to act on them consistently…

If you beat yourself up for losing focus, avoiding necessary tasks, and feeling overwhelmed…

If you’re a dreamer who enjoys brainstorming but struggles with fine-tuning your ideas…

If you struggle with tunnel vision and transitioning between tasks…

If you’re weary from the negative self-talk that often comes with these things…

I’m here to tell you that you’re not lazy or broken and your ideas have value. YOU need your art, and THE WORLD needs your art. Don’t give up. Instead of asking yourself, ‘What’s wrong with me?’ start asking yourself ‘What do i need?’ and pay attention as your mind, body, and soul answer you back. Can you relate to these challenges? Leave a comment below or send me a DM about how these challenges affect your creative callings. 

I also have two invitations for you:

Join me for the 7-day Creative Courage New Year Challenge starting Sunday, January 1.  I’ll be sharing seven daily exercises to overcome creative fears through self-discovery. The challenge will take place in videos on my @writingthelayers page.

Download my free writing guide: 11 exercises to support a creative mindset. The exercises in this guide help you open mental pathways to develop a more flexible and abundance-centered mindset. Available through the link in my bio or allthemanylayers.com/ggreneewrites. You can also DM me the word SHIFT with your email address and I’ll send it to you. ✉️

Lately I’ve been feeling down, like a fog has rolled in. This time of year is historically tough for me, even with my self-care practices and routines in place.

I’d hoped the fog would not come this year, but now that it’s here I’m sheltering in place on hard days (thank you for this metaphor @curlynikki), being gentle with myself, and paying careful attention to the stories my thoughts are telling me. How seductive and familiar hopelessness can be. My heart goes out to anyone struggling with seasonal or any form of depression, and I hope that you are talking about it in therapy and in safe spaces, and I hope you have practices that anchor you.

During S.A.D season—or anytime the fog rolls in—I space things out, and I save my energy for the essentials, so I can keep my core commitments. Yesterday I made sure to give myself extra rest, eat well, drink plenty of water and move slowly. I took a walk. I cried in the shower. I meditated. I filmed my daily video for the Creative Courage New Year Challenge (posted on my @writingthelayers page) and I had an uplifting meeting with @i.am_hope.reviver who spoke life into me as she always does. 

I’m sharing this because I know someone will read this post and know they’re not alone. Maybe someone who is struggling emotionally but doesn’t want to let anyone down. Maybe someone who is chasing their dreams while struggling with mental or physical health issues. Maybe someone who doesn’t have an outlet to transmute what they’re going through. 

I find strength in vulnerability and being emotionally honest, even when it makes people uncomfortable. Creative expression is one gentle way I show up for myself and the world, even when my mind tries to tell me I have nothing to give. I invite you to try the creative reflection prompts above if you’re trying to find your way through the fog. 🙏🏾

It’s the last day of the Creative Courage Challenge! (You can find all 7 days on my @writingthelayers page). Let’s talk about your support system. These are the people you share ideas, challenges + discoveries with. In community, your gifts are honored and appreciated as a source of inspiration for the whole group + you have a space where your uniqueness is valued and affirmed.

Having a creative community builds courage because humans are wired for connection. And there’s something uniquely special about being able to connect with other humans who have similar interests, gifts, passions + challenges. 

Your creative community can understand the nuances of your calling in a way that your chosen family and friends may not. Being a clear channel of who you are and what matters to you allows you to naturally attract the people who will become your creative community. Trust your instincts when that voice inside nudges you to introduce yourself to someone or go to a certain class or event. If you even have one person as your creative community, that’s a huge blessing.

Exercise:

1. If you don’t have a creative community for the intention/calling you are pursuing, where can you start? Decide on an action step, whether it’s joining a group, attending an event, introducing yourself to someone, or even talking to someone you already know about partnering to support each other.

2. If you do have a creative community already, evaluate your level of commitment and how it’s benefiting you. Have you been as consistent and engaged as you could be? Do you need a change or a new challenge? Decide on an action step for deepening your commitment and/or branching out. 

You can go through the steps of this challenge any time throughout the year to breathe fresh air into your creative practice. We take deep dives into these concepts and more in my 6-week Creative Courage Writing Intensive which starts this week on 1/11. Registration closes 1/8 at noon. You can learn more through the link in my bio. ❤️🙏🏾

Finding your lane in the writing world can feel isolating + intimidating, so it’s important to have a clear understanding of your why, and to keep your why at the center of your vision, planning, and decision-making process. 

I started off my writing journey with an influencer mindset which makes sense because I started off as a blogger. It was an accessible way to turn my writing hobby into a career, because I had no writing degree, no connections, no roadmap. I took every opportunity that came to me so I could get some experience + figure out where I felt aligned. I experimented with blogging, freelance writing, ghostwriting, copywriting, course creation + self-publishing. I built an audience by writing vulnerably about my self-discovery journey and offering tools to help others write their truths as well, which created a clear channel for like-minded people to find me. 

But I began to associate likes, follows, and attention with success. I began to think that writing popular posts would lead to more opportunities (which often it does) but when you have this in mind while you’re creating, your creative energy is muddied by your ego + it affects the way you work. Many creatives start out with genuine intentions to grow organically, but then get caught up in the highlight reel of it all. I was one of them. 

You’re easily distracted when you create with your ego at the wheel. Your why needs to be the source of your momentum. If your source of momentum is the validation you get from others, you will succumb to your ego’s interpretation of your results. Your ability to take risks, experiment + learn will be stunted by your fear of poor results + rejection. 

If you are starting from scratch or seeking guidance, the tips in the slideshow offer some insight. I’m also having a pop-up coaching session next week on this topic. Link in bio for details. All registrants receive video replay + self-reflection worksheet. (Free for Inner Story Members)

“Your life is already artful—waiting, just waiting, for you to make it art." — Toni Morrison

There are many ways to find a creative path that expresses your truths and values into the world. Your calling to create may take you on a different course than you expected. 

In my last post I talked about finding your lane as a heart-centered writer and exploring the creative landscape w/out losing yourself. 

After getting distracted by imposter syndrome, one key factor in finding my lane was reconnecting with my reason for writing in the first place. It was about disrupting cycles + silences. It was about personal + collective healing. These reasons became the source of my momentum instead of my ego’s desire to prove my worth.

I found that I wrote with the most ease when I was writing to fellow creatives and storytellers, particularly heart-centered, soulful writers with stories to tell and emotional blocks in the way. Once I got clear on that, it was all about how and where can I find this audience and what can I write for them?

Creative blocks melted away when I stopped paying so much attention to who wasn’t checking for me, and I started pouring love into those who were. To expand my reach, I partnered with creative organizations and communities who served this audience, and I focused on building my own creative community. 

Opportunities to write and facilitate came along that I didn’t expect, and they brought new skill sets, supporters, and ideas for next steps. I found a path that teaches me what I need to know emotionally, creatively, and professionally w/ each step outside of my comfort zone. 

The process isn’t as fast or as sexy as I thought it would be. It’s slower and more sacred, and certainly more ME. 

If you have a calling to expand your writing life, I’m offering guidance in my pop up coaching session this Thursday. Link in bio for details. All registrants receive a recording + a reflection worksheet. Free for Inner Story members.

If you have a calling to write, have you allowed yourself to imagine all the places that calling could take you?

Tonight (thursday 1/19, not next week) I’m having a pop up coaching session about finding your lane as a heart-centered writer, especially for those who don’t come from a writing background.

Many writers and creatives that follow my work have secret, suppressed, or hidden creative callings. They don’t tell anyone that they write or want to write. They don’t feel comfortable owning their creative identities, and the fear of vulnerability shuts down their creative urges.

The way I coach is to use writing as a pathway to your authentic self and as a way to develop empowering narratives for your life. I’ve learned that many of the insecurities that keep us from pursuing our creativity (lack of experience, knowledge, etc.) don’t even matter because the bigger purpose is who you become as you pursue the calling. The stories you tell. The people you touch. The skills you develop. The blessings, surprises, and fulfillment along the way. 

I left corporate america intent on becoming a writer, and it led me to find an unexpected career in coaching, facilitation, and community building. A career where I write from my heart everyday and create tools to help others reclaim their stories and share them with courage. Through this work I have been a grateful witness to storytellers finding their voices, owning their truths, and opening up new possibilities for their creative lives. 

I will share how I experimented to find outlets for my writing and we’ll talk about vulnerability, risk-taking, and developing your craft. Identifying themes you align with, where to submit, and building a writing community will also be covered along with whatever comes up in Q&A. You can submit any advance questions you have through the form. All registrants will receive the replay video and a self-reflection worksheet the next day. 

Link in bio to register.

Reflections on #creativelife and slowing down without getting lost —

I will sing the praises of slow creativity all day, but what about when you’re going slow because you’re overthinking and getting distracted by self-doubt? How do you know when you’re putting off action steps because they’re just uncomfortable and you’re afraid of what they will lead to? 

The only way new things become familiar is through exposure and experimentation. Avoidance will keep you in a cycle of inspiration and frustration because the next step of curiosity is always lighting up in front of you, and as soon as it does, you put obstacles in front of it, you talk yourself out of it, you question the sturdiness of the path and where it’s leading you. 

Go slow. But go steady. Keep showing up. Give yourself tiny experiments to build self-trust. Get to know who you are outside of your comfort zone and inside your own sense of purpose. 

Save this reminder for when you need a creative pep-talk. DM me the word SLOW if you’d like to join my free newsletter community for more creative insights and resources.

Struggle does not have to be your only story. 

You can explore many meanings and interpretations of your life.

You can try to forget your valleys and believe that your life is defined by your peaks. You can wrap your identity around what you've accomplished, without acknowledging the strength that your disappointments gave you.

You can give the valley too much power. You can bury your heart under struggles and misfortunes, overlooking the wisdom you gained from them, the people who loved you through them.

These extremes ignore the layers, the connections between the peaks and the valleys, the risks and the rewards. When you don't find an empowering way to interpret your own story, you become more susceptible to the world's interpretations. When you don't find the value in both the highs and the lows, you’re leaving fulfillment, wisdom, and hope unexplored. 

The moment you realize that you get to interpret your own life, you can begin to reclaim your story. This is a commitment that needs daily attention, because your old story (old ways of being, thinking, and acting) are always right there. They show up in the form of patterns, distractions, and blocks that keep your creative callings stuck in your mind instead of blooming all around you.

Your callings are the daily nudges that invite you to consider: What else could all of this mean? What could I create from this? What story do I want to tell with my life? 

Journal prompts:

What lessons have you learned from your valleys?

What new dreams and visions have developed from your peaks?

“We don't see things as they are, we see them as we are." — Anaïs Nin   
   
Your outlook shapes your experience. We live on this planet together, some of us even live in the same homes and spaces together, but the world we create for ourselves is shaped by our own unique framing, how we make sense of things.    
   
Applying for a job that you don't think you are qualified for could be viewed as a waste of time or it could be an opportunity to step up your resume, practice your interviewing skills and make new connections that could be beneficial in the future.   
   
Taking 15 minutes each morning to journal could seem like another task that you have to make time for, or you could view it as a cumulative practice that will deepen your self-awareness and improve your mental hygiene over time.    
   
Choosing to not engage in an argument with someone who is committed to provoking you may be seen as a sign of weakness, or it can be seen as a sign of wisdom and self-control.    
   
You could view a no as a personal rejection or an embarrassing dead end, or you could view it as a purposeful redirection, part of the figuring-it-out, the beginning of another idea.   
   
There are countless ways to frame any situation, and it's so important that we consciously choose. We don't want our framing to be automatic or reactive, because this is how we find ourselves with lifestyles that don't align with who we are and what we want.

When you read the prompt, what memories, images, feelings, or thoughts come to mind? I can talk about creativity all day. When I talk about it, I’m also talking about aligning with the full expression of who you are. When we separate our creativity from our inner guidance and try to fit a mold or chase an external ideal, we run into creative blocks. Inner guidance speaks to us through our creative urges. If we trust this, then we get to see our creations evolve into authentic expressions and meaningful adventures that we treasure because of the experience and not the result. 

Following my creative urges turned out to be so much more than wanting to write for a living. It’s been a process of unlearning, healing + reclaiming my story. Dealing with my defense mechanisms + coping habits. Changing my relationship with self-worth, ambition + productivity. Learning how to humble myself + be vulnerable + take up space. Understanding my creative process + how I support it or hinder it with my mindset and habits.

Many of us have our creativity stripped away from us in school, jobs, relationships + society at large when we are told that we are too much, not enough, don’t matter, aren’t doing it right, etc. So in my workshops I help people rediscover + understand their creativity so they can work with it, not against it + learn what it needs to thrive. We unravel creative challenges to see what’s at the core, so we can clear a path to the stories, visions + dreams that wait beyond them. 

I invite you to experiment with these prompts on your own, and you can also check out my February online workshops + coaching sessions for the added benefit of guidance and community.

When you have high expectations of yourself, you might think that if your efforts don’t come easily or produce perfect results quickly, you’re doing something wrong. Many of us dreamers, free spirits, over thinkers and sensitive souls are slow to realize our true potential because we don’t see our abilities and challenges clearly, we don’t have a creative process that we trust, and we don’t know how to manage the emotional aspects of creative work.

In Writing Alone and with Others, Pat Schneider teaches, “The roots of a useful discipline lie in understanding ourselves, and that is a gentle matter.” 

Creative development requires self-compassion. We can’t find long-term, reliable flow by working from a place of desperation and force.

Schneider goes on to say, “The wrong kind of discipline damages the creative process. The deepest, truest discipline has its roots in the ancient wisdom of the Hebrew prophet Zechariah: “Not by might, nor by power, but by…spirit.” 
In my workshops and coaching programs, I take my clients through the process of clarifying the authentic needs and intrinsic motivations behind their creative callings. With these subconscious needs clarified, you can feel safe to experiment and even find pleasure in discipline, as you discover the creative process that supports you the way you are.
We all have different patterns, needs, and lifestyles, and we know this, but when it comes to our creative endeavors we tend to look down on ourselves when our habits and patterns differ from what works for other people. 

Do you struggle with discipline when it comes to your creative goals? Share your challenges with me in the comments. 

On my blog, I’m offering some reflection questions and examples so you can apply this to your own situation.

I am taking more pictures this year. I am writing more poems and random thoughts. I am seeing my friends and family in person more often. I am reading more books that are for fun and not for work. I’m becoming a smarter business woman. I am not trying to make sense to everyone. I am listening. I am observing. I am experimenting. I am watching my children turn into adults. I am watching my body age and noticing that my soul doesn’t age. I am embracing the sacrifices that come with the path I’ve chosen. I am knowing that everything is working itself out. I am not acting on old assumptions. I am the same and different and still changing. I am holding both joy and loss at the same time, ease and challenge, confusion and clarity. I am treating each day as a miracle no matter what it brings. 

And so it is.

I saw a post by @coach.carey the other day that said, “Your nervous system is more likely to choose a familiar pain than an unfamiliar joy.”

I love this reminder that discomfort is necessary for growth even though it feels so wrong at first. Familiar pain feels like home. Unfamiliar joy doesn’t feel like joy at all at first, it feels like a sort of death. An old version of you IS dying. An attachment to a belief that doesn’t serve you is dying. 

The thought of this is scary when you don’t know who you’ll be w/out the familiar pain. Like most things, the thought of it is scarier than the reality. 

Sadness used to be my familiar pain. Being sensitive + feeling too much was my excuse for not facing my fears. Under its spell, instead of facing the discomfort of speaking up for myself, setting boundaries, etc. I’d wallow in the comfort of self-pity + self-defeat. Thinking: I can’t get ahead bc life is too hard for people like me. That sort of thing. This would appease me in the short-term, meanwhile my long-term dreams + goals would stay out of reach, on the other side of fear. 

The unfamiliar joy was the freedom of releasing sadness from my identity. I had to stop believing there was something wrong w/ me, that my sadness was insurmountable simply because I’d never let myself feel it without attaching a whole life-defining, disempowering story to it.

Sadness comes and goes + I accept it as part of the full range of human emotion, no longer a permanent obstacle that blocks my dreams + goals. It’s a familiar pain that I have to pass through occasionally + now I pass through w/ curiosity instead of attachment. Asking the sadness what it has to teach me instead of letting it distort my whole vision.

When I was a little girl, I allowed myself to freely dream. “I’m going to make a zillion dollars! That huge one over there is going to be my house! I’m going to have that car! I’m going to have hair down to my butt and I’m going to adopt 10 children!” There was nothing to it. If I could think about it, then I just knew I could do it — once I figured out all the secret things that only grown ups knew. 

Then as I got older, I began to think that something was wrong with me. I still didn’t understand those secret grown up things. I was missing something. My vision narrowed, self-doubt took over, and I began to envision a smaller world for myself. One where I quietly stayed in my lane, not showing too much of myself, afraid to dream and afraid to disappoint. Somewhere along the way, I’d missed the lesson on how to turn dreaming into doing. I thought all I had to do was go to school and get good grades. Check and check. Okay now, where’s my mansion and my car? I’m supposed to want those things right? Where’s my dream job and why am I not happy? 

I was doing what I was told to do, expected to do, and what other people did. My dreams were about acquiring things I thought I was supposed to want. I’d learned how to follow a path that was clearly paved for me, but not how to pave my own way for reasons that inspired me.

The fulfillment you seek, the life that calls you, these callings exist for a reason. It’s never too late to take the journey inside to explore who you really are when you’re honest with yourself. 

When I took that journey, I finally started feeling hopeful about what I could do with my life. The secret things I was looking for on the outside were on the inside all along.

I had a group coaching session last night with my Creative Courage workshop participants and we spent a lot of the time working through the emotional challenges of doing the creative work we are called to do. Procrastination, perfectionism, imposter syndrome, overwhelm, managing distractions, negative self-talk, etc. There are so many distractions + unhelpful habits that get in the way. 

If you struggle with resistance like this, no amount of technical instruction about how to write is going to help you get words on the page. There’s emotional work that needs to be done. Instead of following what you think works for most people, you have to figure out what works for YOU. Going from “I wish this was easier for me…” to “I am committed to experimenting + figuring out what works for me…”

You have to get curious about these blocks + the inner conflicts that are causing them. Creative well-being is influenced by mental, emotional, physical, social + spiritual well-being. My creative life + process changed when I began to approach it holistically, incorporating mindfulness, breath work, physical activity, spiritual practices. Researching habit change. Researching to understand my focus + attention issues instead of trying to threaten + shame myself into doing the work. Having a strict daily routine never worked for me, but working reactively on impulse didn’t work either. Finding a rhythm of habits that support my creative process by providing both structure + flexibility has changed everything. 

These issues w/ resistance don’t just come up with creative projects; they come up with any intention to grow, change, evolve, or expand. If you are stuck in these struggles, join me for my monthly pop-up session on February 22 —  Holistic Creativity: Understanding Your Creative Process Inside and Out. For a long time, I thought that the pursuit of perfection would lead me to achievement which would lead to happiness which would lead to peace. It was one of many stories I told myself that kept me from feeling free. I would come to find out that I could have peace without any of that. 

Let's say perfection is this vision of our lives that we create, a story we tell ourselves about the way things are supposed to be. When we seek perfection, we are really seeking an vision that makes us feel in control.

In my experience, chasing perfection created a pattern of constantly performing and seeking approval. As long as we carry this hidden belief that we have to pretend and perform to survive, we won’t give ourselves permission to explore who we really are and what we really want.

Believing that perfection will bring happiness is one of many hidden beliefs that we must release —  so we can embrace this life experience and see what happens when we start showing up authentically. 

What stories are you telling yourself that keep you from feeling free?

We’ll explore some of these stories together in the Voice and Vision workshop.

Self-discovery often begins with desperation. It becomes an exploration of where it hurts and why, what is heavy and where to put it down. For many of us, this is where the calling to write is born. 

Writing your life stories gives you a deeper understanding of yourself and your experiences. Once you start looking at your life as a story, full of turning points and transformations, you can observe your memories, thoughts and imagination differently. You can discover your ability to reshape the narratives that don’t serve you, and with this awareness you can uncover new storylines for your life that inspire you.

I advocate for personal storytelling as a creative practice because it literally shifted the trajectory of my life and led me to my purpose, but the journey to deeper awareness and fuller expression wasn’t easy. I struggled with shame and avoidance because I didn’t want to face my painful truths, let alone share them. But when I started writing, I found that my unexplored memories held wisdom for me, and eventually, fresh insights and perspectives came to me through the process, my mindset became more flexible, and I started reclaiming my story, one truth at at a time.

So often we don’t start, continue, or finish creative projects because we are afraid that our results will not match our expectations. Sometimes I look back at my early writing and cringe at the rawness and inexperience, but I also realize that I will always be growing in my craft, so I might as well adjust to growing out loud. The cringiness is part of the growth. Putting ourselves out there and being vulnerable is part of the growth. And on the other side of it is expansion.

Can you give yourself permission to look at your creative life, not as a measure of your gifts or worth, but as a practice in getting more comfortable and unapologetic about who you are?

At some point we must accept vulnerability as part of the vision. Before the bylines and books will come lots of what Anne Lamott calls shitty drafts that make you question why you’re writing and if you're making any sense at all. When you go in front of that room full of people, your voice may tremble and you might forget part of your speech. When you sit down to write you might come face-to-face with restlessness, boredom, impatience, and doubt. 

To move through these discomforts, everyone's path is different, but there is this wide-open opportunity to learn self-acceptance through the creative journeys that call to us. In Callings: Finding and Following an Authentic Life, Greg Levoy says: “Art can be a superhighway to rare kinds of emotional maturity. An art practiced over time can become a form of self-study that slowly and steadily builds a matured self-awareness.”

The people who have rejected my art have been some of my greatest teachers. They've taught me to value authentic connections and the fact that being a clear channel means that some people will get it and some won't and that's okay. (And as you can see when you swipe left, some will receive the benefit of your work even when they criticize it! lol)

I have a loud cheerleader in my head telling me that I am enough, but I also have an inner critic that gets loud when I’m tired, overwhelmed, triggered, and out of alignment. And yes, sometimes criticism, rejection, indifference from others can seem to strengthen that inner critic voice that says, “See, I told you that you’re not enough.” This is why it’s so important to be rooted in your why and KNOW your reason for putting your authenticity and art into the world. Your calling is your guiding light, not the praise or criticism you receive for it. 

It’s not the criticism itself that gets in the way of our creative expression, it’s the inner narratives that we tell ourselves in response to it. It’s the self-doubt that we succumb to. One of the ways you can build a lifestyle that’s more conducive to creative thinking and expression is to detach your motivation from praise and criticism.

If we can detach even a little bit, it can help us stay open to expressing ourselves with authenticity and wholeness. If we stop habitually looking for external approval and instead practice looking inside for alignment with our values, we can start taking action from a place of worthiness, and we can set an example of how we want the world to be. When we do this, at the very least, we are creating this world for ourselves, aren't we?

I love to dance. And I still refer to myself as a dancer even though I never danced professionally + haven’t taken classes in years. I’m a dancer because it’s a form of expression that shaped my childhood + womanhood and has always come naturally to me. You don’t have to be a trained professional to own your gifts. When it comes to writing, you don’t have to be recognized as a published writer to develop a powerful writing practice. 

I love the idea that we claim our identities by the steps we take to align with it + when we do this we become a clear channel for people, resources + aligned opportunities to find us. I love that the journey always surprises us. 

While writing has always been a safe space for me, I never thought of myself as a storyteller so much as a good explainer. I thought: Storytellers use vivid imagery, colorful language, and intriguing characters to transport you to a different world. I thought: I left that freedom of imagination in my childhood. 

But— I knew that I expressed myself well when I wrote things down. I could calm myself + say things that I wouldn’t dare say out loud. But a storyteller? No. For a long time that limiting belief stood in the way of the fulfilling work that I do now.

I transformed into a storyteller during my blogging days bc I surrendered to my urge to be vulnerable + share my experiences + I saw evidence that it had a positive impact on my life + the lives of others. I couldn’t ignore that. The more I gave myself permission, the more resources + opportunities appeared + the journey expanded. I didn’t think of myself as a storyteller, but when I discovered that sharing my truth could unlock the truth in someone else, I stepped into that identity + my own embodiment of it. 

You have permission to write your way through life, experiment with your voice + develop your own writing practice that enriches your life. You know that, right? If not, I’m here to remind you!

You can read this affirmation statement before working on a first draft, or anytime you sit down to write and want to get out of your own way.

The intention here is to create a welcome environment for uninhibited thoughts to flow. If you tell yourself over and over how hard writing is, and how you don’t have time, or you hold onto the subconscious belief that your words won’t be good enough and you have something to prove, you are strengthening the wall that blocks the flow. So, change your thoughts, and shift your focus. Don’t judge your early words. Don’t entertain any thoughts of what anyone else might think at this point. The first draft is your playground. Write the way you talk. Let it all out. Your private writing is a place to be free. Tell yourself it’s easy. Tell yourself it’s natural. Tell yourself it matters, even if you can’t see where it’s going. 

🗣️ You don’t get projects done faster by writing perfectly the first time, you get them done faster (and healthier) by not trying to edit and write at the same time, by resting in between drafts, by trusting the process.

Sometimes we don’t recognize this as progress because we were expecting it to look a different way.

Keep your mind open. Stay curious.

Now I support my coaching clients in going from “I wish this was easier for me…” to “I am committed to figuring out what works for me…”

Writing helped me reframe old stories about mental illness + its impact on my life, and my mission is to help others improve the quality of their lives through the power of the written word. 

I grew up with an undiagnosed mentally ill parent + a family that didn’t talk about it. When I began to struggle with my own mental health, I kept it to myself. Not wanting to appear weak or unstable, I thought I could handle it on my own without talking about it—like my family did. After I finally attended my first therapy session at 29 years old, I felt called to contribute to healing discussions around mental wellness. Stories became my lifeline + eventually I found my calling in helping others find their voices.

Growing up in a Black family in the eighties, if there was any discussion about mental illness, it was whispered. Physical ailments were discussed openly, with candor + even humor. The adults would sit around + swap stories about their symptoms, medications and side effects, admitting to pain in their bodies but never in their minds. Mental health issues were sent to church and kept behind closed doors. Watching and listening to the adults, I learned that the worst thing you could do is make yourself look unstable. I learned how to live in denial of what I saw, and felt, and knew; and I learned how to deal with problems by hiding them. 

I reached a point where I realized that this conditioning was having a negative impact on my mental health, relationships, and family life.

Writing has been the alchemy that turned pain and confusion into purpose. 

What life experiences are calling you to the page? (You can see my previous carousel post for ideas.) 

My main three are self-healing (finding a deeper understanding of life and self), game-changing (change patterns from the past and create hope for the future with your story), and teaching (share personal anecdotes to offer guidance, tools, advice). 

We’ll be exploring this in my writing session tonight. Learn more at the link in my bio.✨

Many people will say that there is no such thing as writer’s block, and I understand that perspective. But anyone who has sat down and tried to write only to find their mind blank and uncooperative would likely disagree. We all have thoughts so what keeps us from writing them down? What causes this resistance? Self-judgment. Distraction. Fatigue. So many reasons. Blocks happen when we are out of alignment in some way. 

For example, if my intention is to write about my mental health, but I’m afraid that writing about it will be painful, or that I won’t be able to describe it poetically, or that people will criticize me for what I’ve written, all of these doubts and distractions are going to block the flow of unfiltered expression. 

If I am sleep deprived, or distracted by noise and clutter, or burnt out from a long day, then I’m trying to pour from an empty cup. 

If I am trying to write perfect sentences on the first go and I can’t get more than a couple words out without my perfectionism kicking in, then I’m going to burn out quickly.  You see what I’m saying here?

A creative block holds information. It tells you that something is not aligned. A block gives you reason to pause, ask yourself what you need, pay attention to what truths come up, even when they are inconvenient. Sometimes it’s an emotional inner conflict that needs attention. Sometimes it’s what’s on our plates, our routines, or our mental hygiene. Sometimes we don’t trust our inner voice or the self-discovery process. Resistance occurs when we logically want to take action, but our energy is not aligned.

You don’t have to take a dramatic leap to start trusting your creative urges. Instead of waiting for the perfect conditions, what if you started practicing now in small ways, in baby steps and day-to-day choices?

What if you committed to one act of creative vulnerability each day?

What if you started writing down your ideas instead of keeping them all in your head?

What if you spent less time consuming other people’s art and more time exploring your own?

What if you did one thing a day that your inner artist would enjoy?

What if you found a community that shares your passions and principles?

What if you took a class (or even watch a YouTube video) to learn or brush up on a skill?

What if you carved out a few minutes in the morning or at night for your creative hobby?

What if you revisited a hobby from your childhood?

What if you let go of one thing that you do out of obligation?
What if you journaled to work through fear and resistance?

What if you believed with your whole heart that new choices could lead to new realities?

What’s different about Inner Story is that the monthly workshops are designed for creatives who want to write about their lives, but struggle to move past the emotional resistance that comes with creative expression. You may find yourself inspired one day and stuck the next, frustrated by creative blocks, self-doubt, and inability to focus. The same capacity for deep reflection that calls you to write can lead to constant overthinking and worrying. Your inner conflicts can turn into escapism, avoidance, and procrastination that creates feelings of shame and inadequacy. Finding the right place and the right audience for your writing can begin to feel demoralizing. I know these struggles all too well.

There have been seasons in my journey when I almost stopped believing in my call to write. My struggles with anxiety, overwhelm, self-doubt, and imposter syndrome had me convinced that I wasn’t capable of turning my creative visions into reality. By shifting my inner narrative from ‘What’s wrong with me?’ to ‘What do I need?’, I got curious about my problems and leaned into professional and community support. I discovered that many of my issues came from a lack of self-care, nervous system dysregulation, and a limited understanding of the creative process. Now I teach my clients how to integrate self-care, inner story work and creative development to build the courage and confidence they need to share their stories.

I created the Inner Story Writing Circle to be a safe space for writers who are facing all kinds of creative challenges, based on the understanding that the journey is smoother with the support of community.

Approaching the craft of personal storytelling from the inside out, the content and exercises support the narrative work that cultivates a healthy creative mindset, so you can become the courageous storyteller you are called to be. 

To learn more about the Inner Story Writing Circle, visit www.allthemanylayers.com/inner-story-coaching or link in bio.✨

A few years ago, my mental health sat me down and slowed me down and made me change my approach to work and life in general. 

Once I understood how to fuel my creative process through self-care, I found clarity, focus, and renewed energy.

If you’re new here and you have hidden, suppressed, or blocked creative callings, I have a message for you:

Start your creative journey with a focus on self-care. Not results.

You need self-care for every stage of the process whether it’s getting your ideas out of your head, persisting through self-doubt and uncertainty, or sharing your expression with the world. 

The key to a long-term, fulfilling creative life is understanding your why, what energizes you, what drains you, and what your authentic needs are. Know that your creativity thrives when you take care of yourself—mind, body, and soul. What ‘taking care’ means for each person is unique, and there is so much creative material to discover in defining this for yourself. 

So why not start there? Focus on your well-being and the actions you take will open your creative channel. 

When it comes to challenges:

You won’t always get the results you want. That’s guaranteed.
You will feel painfully vulnerable at times. That’s part of the ride. 

But you can always get meaning from the process if you trust that you will grow from it, that the discomfort will give way to expansion, and that your life is being enriched, no matter the results.

I can talk about creativity all day. You can check out my free resources, workshops, and creative coaching program through the link in my bio.

“I’m not enjoying this process. Why am I doing this again?” One of my coaching clients who is writing about a book about her life recently brought a version of this question to the group. Sometimes our ideas and visions come to us easily, and we feel passionate about them, but the execution proves difficult and we get stuck. We find out that turning an idea into a thing requires self-trust, self-awareness, and straight up emotional labor. 😅

The answer for me has been to slowly and intentionally build a creative practice that I do enjoy and to let my process inform how I approach each project. What feels easy? What feels aligned? What’s an entry point that requires little effort? Start there. Finding a creative practice that you love means you accept yourself for who you are, you know what fills your cup, what moves you to create, what your needs, distractions, strengths and challenges are—so you can allow the fullest expression of who you are to be released. 

Whether you are highly sensitive or not, pursuing your life goals and creative dreams will require that you face your hidden fears and insecurities. It will require you to shine a light on your shadow self and identify the limiting beliefs that want to hold you back. It will require you to know your why and reaffirm it again and again. 

The Sensitive Creative Workshop is an invitation to use the act of writing to reimagine who you are and what you're capable of becoming. Through self-discovery and storytelling exercises, we examine the labels and perceptions that influence our self-concept as sensitive creatives, professionals, and entrepreneurs.

E.B. White: “A writer who waits for ideal conditions under which to work will die without putting a word on paper.”

We often want the creative process to start with an a-ha moment, a spark of inspiration that comes out of nowhere, and then execution. When really, the creative process is happening every moment of the day. As you go through your day, look for life to interact with you, offer you clues, impulses, and ideas.

Trust the relationship you are building with the page. Trust that the page can hold whatever you give it. Let it carry some of the weight. Release any false ideas you have about writing being this compact process where you sit down and magic comes out.  With practice and consistency, writing does indeed come easier, but there is work and conscious commitment that goes into that. 

Your ideas have value, and your resistance is not a sign of laziness. YOU need your art, and THE WORLD needs your art. Don’t give up. Instead of asking yourself, ‘What’s wrong with me?’ start asking yourself ‘What do i need?’ and pay attention as your mind, body, and soul answer you back.

You can check out the resources I’ve created to support you through the link in my bio.✨

Our differences are divine. They’re not accidents. Our differences allow us to offer authentic value and one-of-a-kind energy. Contrary to what society conditions us to believe, what makes us different gives us strength. A strength becomes a superpower when you learn to maximize the benefits and manage the challenges. 

We’ve all seen sci-fi movies where the character has a superpower and they have to learn how to use it, or it could lead to their downfall. Our greatest strengths can become weaknesses if we don’t learn to understand, embrace, and control them. 

Your superpower is a unique quality that gives you a heightened awareness of certain things, an edge or an ability. Maybe your superpower is sensitivity or empathy. Maybe your superpower is building things and creating systems. Maybe you are charismatic and can talk your way into or out of anything. Maybe your superpower is truth-telling. We find our strengths in our willingness to explore our natural abilities. 

What characteristics, gifts, and abilities come naturally to you? You might find yourself thinking of qualities that you’ve been criticized about in your life because sometimes your greatest strength, the thing that ultimately allows you to feel the most purposeful and connected in the world, will be the source of great suffering before it becomes a superpower. 

Build confidence in your differences by knowing them from all sides.

Think about your creative callings and desires. Do you understand why you want them, why they persist? If you have a desire to write, share your story, or make room for more creative expression in your life, what's at the root of it? Following this train of thought can lead you to a fertile starting point and build a reliable commitment. 

I often hear the following sentiment expressed in different ways: "I have stories to tell and I want to write, but I have trouble committing to a routine and writing consistently. I need to figure out how to stick with it."

My approach to this challenge is to take a deeper look at the desire + your mindset around it. 

Simply believing that your desires are yours for a reason is enough for some folks to make room for it, act on it, sacrifice for it. However, some of us have been conditioned to suppress our desires and this is something we have to unlearn. This kind of emotional suppression can lead regret, bitterness, sadness, lack of fulfillment, and overall mental, emotional, and physical distress. 

So when you have a calling and consistently find yourself ignoring it, this is a sign that your beliefs are not in alignment with your desires. 

If you believe that your callings are not important enough, or you question if they'll be worth pursuing, it will be nearly impossible for you to be consistent about nurturing them.

By asking yourself meaningful questions, you can find the fuel and direction you're missing. If you face challenges like this, I invite you to save this post and work on the reflection questions in the carousel.

Join us to understand your creative work on a deeper level and gain confidence by completing a writing project with the support of a compassionate coach + community. Link in bio to learn more.

It’s Mental Health Awareness Month. 

From growing up with a mom who struggled with a mystery condition (later diagnosed as schizophrenia) to becoming a self-medicating, high-functioning adult suppressing stress, anxiety and depression — over the years I've written pages and pages of memories, worries, questions, letters, prayers, confessions and discoveries. Trying to make sense of the fog and confusion and shame. 

Writing has given me an outlet to reframe old stories about mental illness and its impact on my life. 

I used to think that my mother's illness and the silence around it robbed me of my voice, but writing gave my voice back in a powerful way. I find time and time again that when I find the language to write down the story I am telling myself in my mind, I am able to find new meanings and perspectives, and any defeated outlook I am having becomes more flexible and hopeful. I find endless inspiration in creating safe spaces and creative resources to help others find hope and purpose through the power of the written word.

I’m facilitating a two-day writing workshop on May 10 and May 17 for @thewriterscenter on Writing About Mental Illness. We will dig into:

— the benefits of writing and sharing our mental health stories and the fears and obstacles that come with it. 

—how to take care of ourselves as we write and take care of readers when we share about trauma

—how mental illness has directly or indirectly affected our self-concept, our personal relationships, careers, and communities. 

The workshop includes lecture, discussion, and generative writing. Participants will come away with two rough drafts.  If you'd like to join us, you can register through the link in my bio.

It’s 2009ish and I’m a mother of three working in corporate America and afraid to show my creative side publicly so I create a pen name and start a blog with one of my best friends where we write about our self-discovery journeys, womanhood, motherhood, spirituality, all of the things. We call it Peace, Love, and Pretty Things. I write without filter—notes, confessions, poems, essays, declarations from my soul! My diary on display. My becoming on display. It’s an awakening. I feel more comfortable sharing this side of me with strangers than people in my personal life who might be turned off, uncomfortable with my vulnerability. Might judge me. Not take me seriously. The worries seem irrational now, but this is how I felt. These were big fears. Afraid of being seen, taking up space as Gina, so I created GG Renee and she was not afraid. She was inspired and hopeful, and I trusted her. 

From 2009 - 2018, I thought the journey was about building a new way to make a living. But it was really about embracing Regina, Gina, GG, Genie, all these versions and sides of myself and bringing them all into one empowered whole. 

Your calling will require you to face your fears of being seen for who you truly are. Your whole self is needed, even though you are worried about who will look at you differently and how your life and relationships will change if you stop watering yourself down.

Vulnerability will draw people to you AND it will scare people away. 

Allow it.✨

In my twenties, I thought mental illness was something you have or you don’t have. I thought that the average person didn’t need mental health care. Your mind just is what it is + you deal with it. 

I learned that mental illness affects everyone whether it’s direct or indirect. Our mental health is affected by stress, trauma, loss, finances, world events, physical illness, substance abuse + more. We ALL need mental health awareness and a self-care mindset to live fulfilling lives where our special needs, differences, and experiences are part of our value, and not reasons to feel shame or inadequacy.

In 2018, I sought professional help for emotional distress and was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder and later social anxiety disorder. Getting the support I needed and the language to express my struggles started me on a journey that I didn’t expect and am still on to this day, as I continue to discover how neurodivergence affects my personal and professional life.

I bring this journey into my coaching and consulting work to facilitate inclusive conversations around mental health, emotional well-being, and self-care. 

Once you are willing to change the question from “What’s wrong with me?” to “What do I need?” then you can begin to understand how you—and your differences—add a one-of-a-kind value to any environment where you show up authentically. You can stop mourning who you are not, and fully embrace the gifts of who you are. You start making decisions from a place of worthiness instead of inadequacy and finding yourself in relationships and environments where your otherness is valued. 

Taking care of your mental health. Understanding how your nervous system works + what it needs. Developing a self-care mindset. These things require creative courage and a willingness to keep discovering more about the mystery of who you are. You can learn more about my approach at allthemanylayers.com.

One truth at a time. This is how we reclaim our stories. 

The truth is, I spent years trying to hide my heart. I always felt like I was having a different experience than everyone else, and that no one would understand or care about my heart-centered, soul-focused point of view.

It was an inconvenience. To feel so deeply and drift off into my inner world so easily. Why couldn’t I just accept the surface level. Why couldn’t I just keep my feet on the ground. It seemed that life would be easier if I could.

I fought against this part of me. Numbed it as much as possible. I believed when people told me that my sensitivity was a weakness. I believed the inadequacy I felt when I couldn’t find work that matched my gifts. I made choices that ignored my needs and then I wondered why I felt so lost and afraid. I know now that it couldn’t have been any other way. 

One truth at a time. This is how we reclaim our voices. Our stories. Our lives. Our attention. This is how we make meaning from the scattered pieces.

Writing is how I carved out a place for myself and found the courage to be seen. 

When you speak your truth, your story can be a source of strength instead of weakness. When your story becomes a source of strength, your life transforms. 
It couldn’t have been any other way because I needed to learn so I could teach. And be a catalyst for other sensitive, heart-centered folks with stories and testimonies that the world needs. 

Fear is contagious. Fitting in is contagious. But so is love. So is vulnerability. So is creativity.

In the Creative Courage Writing Intensive, we break this heart-centered work down into practices and processes. We remove pretense and ego, so our voices and stories can thrive. I’m writing this directly to the souls that have been craving fuller expression. To learn more, click the link in my bio or DM me to inquire. ✨

With me, it starts with blessings. I get busy with opportunities and I have a deadline to meet or an unexpected interruption and I skip my daily walk. For a day or two. Then I start skipping my morning spiritual programming: meditation, reading, journaling. High on the dopamine of moving from task to task, I start to feel like I’m good without my rituals. I got this. Just for a bit longer, anyway, so I can keep up this pace and finish this project and then this one and this one. I’m staying up later and getting up earlier. Chores and mail pile up. Phone calls and texts go unreturned. And next thing I know, I’m overwhelmed, agitated, finding fault in everything I lay my eyes on, especially myself. 

All because I was busy and had so many things to do that I started skipping my necessities. Putting me in a state where my foundation is wobbly, I’m more easily triggered, the wobbles are bigger and longer than usual, and the intrusive thoughts more aggressive. Recently I’ve been taking my own advice and coaching myself. Switching from What’s wrong with me? to What do I need?

Over the years, I’ve had to change my whole way of thinking and being in the world to manage anxiety + heal from years of unhealthy coping mechanisms. I expand and then I wobble as I adjust to the expansion. I have to be reminded that I can have more, receive more, without burning myself out and sacrificing my needs. That taking care of myself is gratitude in action which attracts what I want so I don’t have to push. So this is a reminder to you too: 

When you make it out of a hopeless place, don’t stop doing the things you did to break free. 

Keep up the healthy rhythms that have been sustaining you. 

Keep doing the things your future self will thank you for.

…

“We must do our work for its own sake, not for fortune or attention or applause.”
― Steven Pressfield

Creative courage often starts in solitude, when we dare to tell ourselves the truth, and explore what's going on in our inner worlds. We risk the initial discomfort of self-discovery for the hope and meaning it provides, not for fortune or attention or applause. When we focus on the extrinsic factors, we often find ourselves blocked, cut off from the inspiration that motivated us in the first place.

Whether you write for your own healing or to show up in the world in a more authentic and purposeful way, it's a practice that becomes easier when you find a way to take the pressure off, so it doesn't feel like work or a way to prove your worth. If you're struggling with writing, forget about your goals for a while and go back to a time when writing was a way to free your imagination, or a way to connect with someone, or whatever positive impact it has had on your life. Go back to that feeling and try writing from that place. Maybe you go back to being a child with your first diary. Or writing a love letter to your first love. No expectations. No judgments. Just curiosity and acceptance and wholeheartedness. Imagine what could bloom in that environment.

Judgment is a creativity killer. In creative circles, we often talk about not judging ourselves, but many of us don’t realize that judging others also inhibits our creativity. 

If we value the freedom to express ourselves authentically and experiment with our creative voices, then we need to be able to give others the same space that we want for ourselves. This is not always easy. 

But it is possible to be discerning about what you like and don’t like without making judgments about what’s good or bad, what’s worthy and what’s not. When I’m not a fan of a particular writer’s work, I resist the urge to question their success. Because I know that everyone is not for everyone and being judgmental stifles my mental flexibility and acceptance of difference. I can appreciate the artist, even if I’m not a fan of the art. Constantly making judgments stifles my creativity. 

You can learn a lot about where you need to let go in your own process by noticing what you judge in other people. Do you value authentic creative expression more than you value approval and validation? How does what you value show up in your actions? Reflect on your creative fears and how they show up in the judgments you make about others.

One of the things I love about writing is how it allows us to externalize our problems, inner conflicts, and struggles.

Because while we all experience problems, we are #not problems ourselves, and yet we tend to attach our problems to our identities. This is a subtle shift in thinking, but a powerful one.

Often we are conditioned to hide problems, mistakes and hardships and to believe that when we have them we should be ashamed. So when we struggle, we are not only dealing with the objective situation. We are also dealing with our emotional reaction to it and the belief that this struggle shouldn't be happening. But problems are information. They are experiences. They hold wisdom for us. They are necessary. 

As a creative coach, a lot of my work with clients involves externalizing inner conflicts, getting them out in writing so they can be observed, questioned, and turned into art. This is one of the many ways that writing can be a friend to us. An ally that is always there to help us find our way through our inner and outer worlds. 

This is what we'll be exploring together in the next Practice session which is coming up this Saturday morning, July 1 at 10 am et. Many writers and creatives come to me for mindset work. Some want to know how to create in such a way that it doesn’t feel like a waste of time, or they want to guarantee a quantifiable success. Instead I challenge them to develop a more fulfilling and sustainable way to define success for themselves. A definition that has nothing to do with results or what people think.

Some want to know how to overcome the uncomfortable feelings like uncertainty, doubt, and awkwardness that come with creative expression. I teach them mindset shifts that allow them to move through these emotions mindfully with self-compassion and curiosity. I teach them how to integrate these uncomfortable emotions into the art itself. 

Some want to know how to use social media without pretending and performing. I tell them to look at it as another source of creative exploration, a way to practice vulnerability, and an opportunity for play and experimentation.

Some want to know how to reach a lot of people and build a big following and I guide them to focus on connecting with one person, an ideal reader, a target audience, who is just waiting for their unique point of view. 

My approach to coaching is to put the art first. 

Create for the sake of creating.
Don’t attach your motivation to a certain result, instead fall in love with the process.

You won’t always get the results you want. That’s guaranteed.

You will feel painfully vulnerable at times. That’s part of the ride. 

But you can always get meaning from the process if you trust that you will grow from it, that the discomfort will give way to expansion, and that your life is being enriched, no matter the results.

“The work wants to be made, and it wants to be made through you.”
― Elizabeth Gilbert

When you think you don't have time for self-reflection and creative expression, you can start by thinking about where you can insert small pauses in your day to just breathe + be still.

Maybe you take ten minutes after your morning meeting to find somewhere quiet to pause.

Then think about where you can insert slightly longer pauses in your week. Maybe an hour to yourself after work on Tuesday.

Then look at the month. Choose a half day to block off for time alone. These are suggestions that you can customize to your situation + needs. 

What you do during your pauses requires some practice and experimentation on your part. You might read, do breathing exercises, journal, doodle, or pray during your 10 min pause. You might use your weekly hour to research a topic you're curious about that's been on your mind but you haven't made the time. 

Your half day? So many possibilities. You can take an artist date (google if you’re not familiar). Try a new recipe and get creative in the kitchen. Go for a drive. This time is for you and you only, to give yourself the same attentiveness you would give someone else on an actual date. 

Choosing to press pause on life's pace, demands, and expectations is a quiet but powerful way to take your power back.

I got a question about this in yesterday’s post (thanks @glitterandbefae!) so I decided to make it a series. Being diagnosed with ADHD made so many things make sense in my life, and it has had a major impact on how I view my creative process. So many of the workarounds I’d discovered to manage my focus and attention are being confirmed as I research practices to support attention disorders. 

Even if you aren’t neurodivergent, you live in a world where we all face overstimulation. We all, on some level, deal with stress, anxiety, and trauma that affect our executive functions like managing impulses, prioritizing tasks, and choosing where to focus attention. So these tips can help anyone who struggles with sustaining motivation for their creative projects.

So you might find yourself avoiding difficult, unfamiliar, and emotionally uncomfortable tasks, even if those tasks align with your values and are necessary for your growth, goals, and well-being. If you’re working on a long-term project, especially one that involves creative vulnerability, you’re going to need a plan. You’re going to need help. You’re going to need willingness and curiosity. I hope some of these ideas help. 

Remember that just because you struggle with motivation doesn’t mean you're lazy or that the project is not important to you. I struggled with my book proposal for more than a year by myself, but once I started working with accountability partners and groups, I got it done in six months at a pace that was comfortable for my life. I let go of the timeline and just focused on showing up for the daily chunks, asking for help when I got lost, and celebrating the milestones. 

I’ll continue this series with more on task avoidance strategies and how to enjoy (and not feel let down) when a project is finished. Feel free to share more of your creative challenges in the comments.✨
