In the coming weeks I’ll be sharing weekly tips on the creative process. This week, I’m talking about creative resistance. I’m excited about this new series, but all day I felt kind of nervous, avoiding it, even though it’s something that is aligned with who I am + not particularly difficult. More often than not, the resistance is much harder to get past than the task itself.

Telling you about my weekly video intention is a way to hold myself accountable and embrace imperfection. This method works for me. I’ve learned this about myself after years of struggling with task avoidance and not having a name for it. 

I used to think that tapping into the energy of others to help me show up for myself was a weakness. But a few things changed that. One was studying the creative process as a creative coach. Two was my adhd diagnosis. Pre-diagnosis, there was always some shame that came with my resistance. Why can’t I “just do it” like people are always telling me? Why can’t I get my heart and mind to cooperate? Learning that my brain works differently got the shame and confusion out of the way, so I could focus on solutions.

One solution is getting help w/ accountability. Over the last couple years, I’ve learned how to ask for help. I asked people to set aside time to write with me. I asked people to read my work. I asked people to hold me accountable. I made commitments to show up for others consistently. 

In doing so, I built stronger muscles in working with my resistance + circumstances: my habits, triggers, moods, learning curves, etc. You don’t have to be neurodivergent to experience resistance and avoidance to tasks that you know are important + worthwhile. It’s all about being honest + compassionate w/ yourself as you experiment with ways to work through it. 

By asking for help, I not only developed greater self-trust, but also greater trust in the process. 

Here’s how you can act on this tip. Give yourself a small, teeny tiny goal, something super accessible, and ask for support in meeting that goal.

When working on a long-term creative project or even just trying to maintain consistency with your creative practice, understanding how you work and blending the process into your life is key. 

We often think our ideas and solutions come from sheer effort, like we can squeeze the brilliance out if we just work enough hours or drink enough coffee. Sometimes we even think that if we were just ‘more creative’ we would have a more steady flow of ideas. 

But we are all part of a universal creative process, and we can make things easier for ourselves by working with it and not against it. Think of your temperament and your pace as tools to learn how to use and not as obstacles. 

If you are neurodiverse and tend to hyper-focus and struggle with interruptions and shifting gears, this is especially important for you. Teach your nervous system that it’s safe to step away from the effort and come back to it. That the flow won’t leave you and never come back. Lol. (Because that’s how it feels sometimes! I get it!) 

Look at rest as a productive part of your creative process. This is the part where we disconnect from the idea, the conscious effort, for a period of time. We often underestimate this phase and try to skip it! We might think that we are stuck or blocked, when really we just need time to process. While our thinking minds are busy with other parts of our lives, our subconscious, or higher power, does the creative work. Awareness of this step shows us that the creative process requires a partnership between intellect and intuition. 

As a creative coach, I offer group and 1:1 experiences to help you understand the deeper layers of your creative process and motivation. Stay tuned for more tips.

It’s my life’s work to help people discover and reclaim their stories, starting with reimagining my own defeated story. Combining my professional experience as an author, coach, and facilitator with my personal journey as a black woman, self-healer, and mental health advocate, I’ve spent the past ten years creating blogs, books, journals, workshops, and coaching programs that center writing as a tool for healing, personal growth, and expression.

This summer I signed with Ashley Hong @ashleysunghae at Gardner Literary to bring more of this work into the world, empowering more readers to look at their lives through fresh eyes through the power of self-inquiry and storytelling. My book-in-progress explores how I went from living a defeated story to walking in my purpose, and how we can all do this by treating our life experiences as creative material that we have the power to shape.

I bring this same energy to my creative community every Sunday night through life reflection exercises that inspire curiosity, unlearning, and reimagining, to support them in developing a creative vision for their lives. In my coaching programs, we write to heal, just as much as we write to share our gifts with the world. The content and exercises support the inner narrative work that cultivates a healthy creative mindset, so they can be the committed writers + storytellers they want to be. 

I created a safe space for writers who have persistent creative callings that come with persistent creative challenges, based on the understanding that the journey is smoother with the support of a mentor + community. I have the @permissiontowrite and @writingthelayers communities to thank for helping me reach this milestone of becoming an agented author. I wake up grateful everyday that I listened to the small voice and found this abundant path even with all of the uncertainty + confusion  along the way. You never know where the journey will take you. I’m just thankful for the ride.

I’ve been stripping down and preparing myself to step into deeper layers of vulnerability in this space, in my work. The book I’m working on has me facing things I avoided for years and healing the little girl inside who is still confused, afraid, and hiding. 

This is not light work. But the elevation that comes from getting your story out is like a weight off your back. It turns your life struggles into treasure hunts for meaning and for wisdom. So that’s what this project is for me. That’s what life is, really. A treasure hunt. 

What treasure hunt are you being called to?

Start with your why. If you want to express yourself in a new way, why? If you want to share your creative work in a bigger way, why? 

Being unclear on your why is a big reason our intentions fizzle. Your why is the foundation of your resilience and your courage, so if your why is based on satisfying your ego, it will not provide long-term momentum or conviction.

You might think of your ego as the part of you that craves attention but it doesn’t always express itself that way. 

Ego can show up as the fear of being seen. It can show up as playing down your gifts to avoid judgment. It can show up as knowing what you want, but not asking because you fear rejection. It can look like delaying your happiness until you feel more worthy. 

Ego wants you to stay small and save face. Ego can keep you locked up tightly in a life that doesn’t make room for individuality, creativity, or vulnerability. 

Ego can keep you stuck in a limited version of yourself that is too occupied with defending itself to tap into higher instincts. This is how it blocks your creative flow.

Let’s talk about task avoidance and creative projects. You may call it procrastination or creative blocks or a lack of discipline. Clients often tell me that when they set aside time to write, they suddenly get the urge to do any + everything else. They suddenly have nothing to say. This is not because of a lack of creative material. It’s because of fear, self-doubt + subconscious limiting beliefs. We can work through creative blocks by seeking deeper self-understanding.

Sometimes we need to go deeper to explore the block that exists between the intention and the action. Task avoidance refers to a pattern of behavior where an individual actively avoids or postpones completing a task or activity. While it is often associated with neurodivergence, task avoidance can occur for a variety of reasons, including mental health issues like depression and anxiety, as well as uncertainty, perfectionism, overwhelm, or fear of failure.

I began to investigate my issues with task avoidance before I knew what it was called. I just knew that there was an invisible wall between me and my long-term goals. Not just writing goals, life goals too. I wanted to understand why I avoided things that I actually enjoy doing. Why I avoided tasks that were important to me, that improved my mental and physical health in ways that I craved—until it was time to do them. I had a creative vision for my life and task avoidance was in my way, which also resulted in shame that only made the vision even more out of reach. I began to experiment with strategies to work around it + it wasn’t long before I saw change. I’m sharing a few of those strategies above.

So when I hear someone say they are struggling to start, continue, or finish a creative project, it becomes a discussion about mindset and process, not ability.

One truth at a time. This is how we reclaim our voices. Our stories. Our lives. 

Many writers and creatives have secret, suppressed, or hidden creative callings. They don’t feel comfortable owning their creative identities, and the fear of vulnerability shuts down their imaginations.

My coaching programs center writing as a pathway to authentic expression. I’ve learned that many of the insecurities that keep us from pursuing our creativity (lack of experience, knowledge, etc.) don’t even matter because the bigger purpose is who you become as you pursue the calling. The stories you tell. The people you touch. The skills you develop. The blessings, surprises, and fulfillment along the way. 

Writing is how I found my voice and the courage to be seen. Little did I know when I was struggling to find my way that I would one day use what I was going through to become a mentor for other heart-centered creatives with stories + testimonies that the world needs. 

I created the Reclaim Group Coaching program for purpose-driven creatives who want to grow within a supportive, interactive process designed to bring their inner visions out of hiding. By helping my clients and participants understand their creative process from the inside out, and develop positive life habits that nourish their creative potential; I empower them to reimagine the stories they tell themselves and the world.

If you're ready for personalized support for a creative project or goal, the Mastermind Mentorship is a three-month, small group coaching container that offers 1:1 guidance + accountability, plus community support for navigating the strategic + emotional challenges that come with the creative process.

You just finished a project, and you feel sad, maybe even depressed. Post-project sadness is an emotional depletion that can occur after releasing a creative project into the world. Above are some ways to cope with it.

I think this sadness is often unexpected because we put so much effort into the project— we shed a whole layer of ourselves to get it done—and we think only of the joy we’ll feel when we’re done, but in reality, finishing brings mixed emotions. Joyful about the accomplishment. Sad to let it go. Scared to share what you made. Maybe critical of how it turned out. Worried about what’s next. Overwhelmed with all these emotions. 

This is another reason to fall in love with the whole creative process, every part of it. Maybe you want to reignite your creative spark, explore your life story, start a blog or business around your passion, build a platform or community, find a new direction in your career, enhance your leadership and advocacy skills through storytelling, or rediscover your creative voice and see where it leads you.

It’s not a question of IF you can do it; it’s a matter of knowing that the HOW might surprise you.

I left corporate america in 2013 intent on becoming a writer, and it led me to find an unexpected and fulfilling career in coaching, facilitation, and community building. Through this work I have been a grateful witness to storytellers finding their voices, owning their truths, and opening up new possibilities for their creative lives.

Whether your calling is general or specific, maybe you’re not sure how it will affect the rest of your life, or if you’re willing to risk the familiarity you have for the fuller expression you crave.

Maybe ‘creative living’ seems like something other people do, or it seems like you can’t get there from where you are because of your roles, limitations, and responsibilities.

I have close friends that I’ve been friends with since childhood. I have friends and acquaintances that I don’t speak to on a regular basis, but have deep love + forever connections. I have a loving family who supports me up close and from far away. I feel so supported, but I don’t expect my loved ones to be my creative community. 

I don’t expect them to be as interested in self-discovery + creative process + writing books as I am. I don’t expect them to understand the nuances that come with this particular journey. A creative community can understand your calling in a way that your family + friends may not. 

Being a clear channel of who you are + what matters to you allows you to naturally attract the people who will become your creative community. Trust your instincts when that voice inside nudges you to introduce yourself to someone or go to a certain class or event. If you even have one person as your creative community, that’s something to treasure. 

There’s something so energizing about being able to connect with other humans who have the same interests, gifts, and passions. We speak each other’s language. We are each other’s accountability partners, vision holders, cheerleaders + expanders. We share discoveries, breakthroughs, challenges, wins, and losses. 

I used to struggle with community because I’m an introvert + tend to isolate myself. But someone gave me some perspective that changed the course of my journey. They said to connect with people who are working towards where you are that you can pour into, peers that you are working alongside with, and then mentors who are pouring into you. This dynamic creates a sort of ecosystem of knowledge sharing, generosity + emotional support that makes the journey even more satisfying.

If you are a heart-centered writer who is missing the community and mentorship pieces of the puzzle, you can learn more about my offerings through the link in my bio.

I’m here to tell you that you’re not lazy or broken and your ideas have value. YOU need your art, and THE WORLD needs your art. Don’t give up. It’s not a matter of if you can do it, it’s a matter of figuring out what works for you. 

According to research, actualizing creative goals requires a combination of dreaming and doing and we all fall somewhere on the spectrum with characteristics of both. When seeking creative support (or working on your creativity on your own) it’s important to be aware of where you fall on this spectrum, to understand who you are as a creative person: your motivations, your innate gifts, and your challenges. 

For example, maybe you are full of ideas but struggle to get them out of your head and into words and plans. Maybe you are organized, systems-oriented, and never miss a deadline, but struggle to connect with your intuition and be vulnerable enough to bring forth the deeply authentic work that conveys your one-of-a-kind life message. 

Whether you are more of a dreamer or more of a doer, you need access to both energies to create momentum in your creative life and trust me the benefits of this awareness spills over into the rest of your life.

This understanding is what enabled me to go from overwhelm, burnout, lack of direction, and time + energy scarcity to a lifestyle where my creative, personal, and professional life are all aligned and feeding into each other. Where I integrate my dreamer strengths with my doer challenges and find a steady flow of inspiring opportunities.

I used to sit in meetings at work and daydream about the books I wanted to write. 

When I took a leap of faith and started to pursue my writing, I created a pen name so I could keep my creative writing separate from my corporate identity. I wrote at lunchtime, late at night after putting the kids to bed, in parking lots while chauffeuring them around. Awakened, I couldn’t stop if I wanted to. 

My first self-published book was about heartbreak + healing. My second self-published book was about discovery + finding my voice. My third self-published book was about sharing the writing + self-discovery techniques that I’d been using to release my stories from their hiding places within me. 

Layer by layer, I was becoming more free. I was also burning out, exhausted from trying to answer my callings + still be who everyone in my life expected me to be.

My next two books reflect the lifestyle changes that empowered me to create from overflow instead of depletion and desperation. I’d learned that if we don’t prioritize self-care, if we don't nurture our mental and physical health, this will affect how our thoughts and ideas develop, and how we express ourselves overall.

My current work-in-progress is about exploring our layers + reclaiming our stories to find a creative vision for our lives. 

When I stand back + reflect on the journey, I’m so thankful that I leaped. I’m thankful for the inner ache that let me know I wasn’t where I was supposed to be or doing what I was supposed to be doing. I’m thankful that I fell down over and over again + learned the art of getting back up. I’m thankful that I didn’t continue betraying myself + suppressing my truth. I’m thankful to pour what I’ve learned into my clients + community.

If you are stuck btwn who you’ve been + who you are called to be, enrollment in my last mastermind of the year is open until this Friday, 8/25. You can learn all about it thru the link in my bio. DM me with the word MENTOR to ask questions. ✨

Sometimes we want to write, but we struggle to get started, or we get bored with our routine way of doing things. One way we can add some novelty to the practice is by experimenting with prompts to get the juices flowing. 

 So I create these lists for my community every month, and on the first Friday, we gather on Zoom and freewrite together. It’s become a treasured part of my creative ecosystem. Creating the lists feels like play; it centers me and pulls me into a state of ease. I look forward to it. I think about the stories and connections that will be inspired by these phrases. Then, gathering with the writers every month and seeing how vulnerable and generous everyone is with each other’s art fills my cup every time. 

So how can you use this list? Well, there are no specific rules. When you look over it, what memories, images, feelings, thoughts, or stories come to mind? The prompts might give you the urge to write a fictional story, poem, reflection, list, essay, or something that defies category. If you’re a visual person, they can be used to inspire photos, sketches, or paintings. 

 The only directions I’ll offer are to sit down with the list and a journal and pen or whatever device you love and choose a prompt that sparks a train of thought that gets you writing. One thing that can really help to get the flow started is to let the prompt trigger a thought without getting attached to where your words take you. Using these prompts as triggers, you can explore your voice and impulses in a no stress way. 

 If you enjoy writing in community, you are also welcome to join us for our free monthly workshop tonight at 7 pm et where we'll be freewriting from these prompts. New faces are always welcome, and sharing is optional. Swipe left for my other upcoming September workshops (links in bio).✨

When you’re pregnant, the best thing you can do is surrender to the divine process and your role in it by taking the best possible care of yourself. You are the vessel for this life growing inside of you.  You can’t force or rush the outcome. You nurture this growing life through water, prenatal care + nutrition, exercise and loving thoughts. The rest is up to a higher power. The result is a perfectly imperfect manifestation that forever changes and expands you in ways that you never could’ve  imagined. 

We need this same surrender when it comes to the books, paintings, screenplays, music, projects, businesses, etc. that we conceive.  These ideas have a gestational period as well. The best thing we can do with an idea that we want to grow is to take care of ourselves, mind, body + soul, and be a healthy place for that idea to develop. The rest is up to a higher power that can only work through us if we show up, open-hearted, curious, and willing. 

I'll be talking more about this on my new Substack. How self-care allows the fullest expression of who you are to be released. How writing is a spiritual journey for me and how this affects my approach to the business of writing, this combination of surrender and strategy. How I'm learning that creativity is not something you can compartmentalize and expect it to flourish. I'll be sharing the revelations that come along with writing this book I’m working on and manifesting a creative vision for my life that I once thought impossible.

The weekly exercise that went out to my membership group this week was called Choose Your Own Adventure. This is a decision-making, direction-finding process that improves the quality of your life. Not because it removes struggle and challenge, but because it takes you on adventures that expand you as opposed to keeping you stuck. It aligns your life circumstances with your truths and values, your authentic self. Instead of aligning with limiting beliefs, fears, and doubts. 

When faced with a decision, you ask yourself what kind of experience (or adventure) you want to have. Do you want an adventure that aligns with your authentic self or do you want an adventure that aligns with your fearful self? This perspective effectively eliminates the choices that don’t align with your values. 

So imagine that each decision you make is sending you on an adventure. Which options will send you on an adventure that invites more of what your authentic self wants to experience?

This process may not get you all the way to one specific choice, but it will narrow things down, and whatever you decide you’ll know that you’re choosing an adventure that aligns with your soul, embodies meaning and purpose, and enhances your life in some way. 

I specialize in working with purpose-driven writers and creatives who want to explore their life experiences through writing and bring their creative callings to life. To get involved, you can click the link in my bio to access free resources and learn more about my programs. ✨✨

“If it doesn’t hurt, is it even real? 

Before I became a mom with three young kids who distanced herself from her mother, I was a teenage girl who thought that love was supposed to hurt. I was attracted to the boys who drew me in then ignored me. I craved acceptance from the girls who were cooler than me. I was drawn to relationships that included some guesswork and performance. The uncertainty was familiar to me. I developed this pattern from my relationship with my mother. 

 How your mother sees you has a big impact on how you see yourself. From the day my mother first started with the bizarre accusations, I began chasing the high, trying to get love and trust to return, to wrap me up and make me feel safe again. I knew she loved me, but so often, she was disappointed in me, mostly for things I didn’t do or couldn’t help. Without realizing it, I associated all love with this emotional roller coaster and my heart began to crave the familiarity of this cycle. 

 Love that plays hide-and-seek. Love that rains and shines without warning. Love that doesn’t want you to go and doesn’t want you to stay. I accepted what I thought was reality: We can’t keep all of ourselves if we want to be loved.”

Sharing a little bit of an early, rough draft of my #wip. You have to tell yourself the story first, you know? Are you carrying around a story that you need to tell?

"You are not your illness. You have an individual story to tell. You have a name, a history, a personality. Staying yourself is part of the battle." — Julian Seifter

Over the years I've written pages and pages of memories, worries, questions, letters, prayers, confessions and discoveries. Trying to make sense of the fog and confusion and shame that I suppressed in my childhood and young adult years. 

Writing is central to my mental and emotional self-care. Storytelling, in particular, has been key to reclaiming my voice and finding community. 

I find time and time again that when I find the language to write down the story I am telling myself in my mind, I am able to find new meanings and perspectives, and any defeated outlook I am having becomes more flexible and hopeful. I find endless inspiration in creating safe spaces and creative resources to help others find hope and purpose through the power of the written word.

—how to take care of ourselves as we write and take care of readers when we share about trauma

The workshop includes lecture, discussion, and generative writing. Participants will come away with two rough drafts.  If you'd like to join us, you can register through the link in my bio.

In the midst of all the suffering, I turn to art and language and hold on for dear life.

I’ve been thinking about how innocent babies turn into hateful, heartless adults. Hate comes from a heart frozen with pain, denied the freedom to feel, to flow, to expand and hold more than one truth; a heart constricted with fear. Hate weakens the heart making it impossible to hold the plurality that love requires. Every human carries the pain and suffering of the human condition in their DNA. How do we keep suffering from turning into hate? 

Michelle Cassandra Johnson (@skillinaction), author of Finding Refuge: Heart Work for Healing Collective Grief, says that collective grief can be very shadow-like, and it’s important to name it. 

“People are grieving all the time and not acknowledging it. I think we need to recognize that people are moving around brokenhearted. How does that manifest physically, emotionally, mentally, spiritually?” 

A few prompts for reflection:

What emotions come up when faced with the world’s suffering? What thoughts, impulses, and urges? Do you shut down? Feel survivor’s guilt? 

Do you struggle with how to help and feeling helpless? What “shoulds” are you imposing on yourself, if any? Are you expecting too much or too little of yourself?

What actions, thoughts, or situations deepen your fear, anger, rage at the world’s suffering? What actions, thoughts, or situations strengthen your hope?

Freewrite to explore and express this complexity and know it, so that fear doesn’t branch out, untended and wild in your heart. Name your grief. Claim your peace. 

What does healing and unity look like in your space, your family, your community, in the lives you touch? What resources can you share?

Inspired by Rebekah Taussig’s quote above: What practices allow you to hold it all? The outrage and comfort, grief and levity, anxiety and openness, strain and resilience, devastation and creativity?

Don’t know who needs to hear this, but it’s on my heart to say to all the sensitive artists out there: LET IT GO. Don’t let rejection swallow you up. Don’t take it personally: the rejection, the indifference, the silence of non-response. Feel it, know it, but don’t hold onto it. 

According to research, in a study where subjects attached to an MRI machine were asked to recall a recent rejection, the area of the brain that lit up was the same area that lights up when we experience physical pain. So being rejected can affect your brain in the same way as if you were being physically hurt. I find this information helpful, so I can understand the feeling on a physiological level, know where it’s coming from and let it go. 
 
My nervous system struggles with rejection. It annoys me that my first instinct is to take it personally and question my value. This is old programming that I am still releasing. This is the work. To me, this is the whole point. To see through the initial pain. To grow beyond my reactive perception to the wider view beyond it. 

Rejection will question you. It will question your conviction and devotion. It will question your spirit and your ego. It will ask you to remember what your effort is for, what you are seeking, and why. Rejection will even create illusions that convince you that it’s there when it’s not. 

When you’re ready to reframe it, rejection reminds you that art is about vulnerability and generosity. It’s a form of love, and sometimes it’s unrequited. The point is to love anyway, to make the art anyway, and keep your heart and mind open to the intimate rewards: the life lessons, the soul growth, the peace of mind that comes with sincerity. 

The more you trust your expression, in spite of uncertainty, the more freedom you grant yourself. The stronger you become in self-compassion and commitment to your craft for the sake of itself. Feel the discomfort and let it go. We need your art. Keep creating.

“Criticism is my default, and compassion is a practice.” When I read this line in @ltinthecity’s book Stop Waiting for Perfect, I paused to let it sink in. Because why is it that compassion for others comes so naturally to me, but it’s been a constant uphill climb to cultivate compassion for myself? Why is this something that so many of us—particularly women—struggle with? 

In her book, L’Oreal offers context through research findings and transparency through her own personal stories. She provides actionable tools that can be practiced and applied in your daily life to gradually become aware of negative self-talk and implement ways to build your own self-compassion practice. 

I particularly like the one where you picture your younger self. She says, “I think back to five-year-old L’Oreal and imagine myself saying those things to her. I can’t. To do so is both unimaginable and cruel to an nth degree. Younger me needed someone to lift her up, to reminder her that her voice is worthy and her ideas and opinions matter. Perhaps younger you needs that reminder, too. Or present day you. No matter how old we get, we carry our younger selves with us. Might as well be kind to them, too.” 

Tomorrow evening we are gathering for the 9th session of The Practice with journals and pens to talk and write about our inner critics. L’Oreal will help us identify our inner critics; guide us through a powerful journaling exercise where we will pen breakup letters to our inner critics; and learn self-compassion exercises to use when negative self-talk inevitably tries to get in the way.

Come practice with us! This session is free for members, or you can drop-in for $15. Link in bio.

You can grab a copy of Stop Waiting for Perfect wherever you get your books, or you can visit LTinthecity.com/book to learn more.

What a blessing it is to age. My birthday just passed and I thought about posting 46 lessons for 46 years. I thought about posting nothing at all. But something kept nudging me to share. When most people ask how does it feel to be 46, they probably want a simple answer, but I don’t really do simple answers, so here’s what I got.

At 46, I’m reflecting on evolution, because that’s what birthdays represent to me. How am I evolving. How am I paying attention in a world that offers so many reasons to look away. 
How am I integrating all the joy and pain of the circle of life. 

At 46, I want to notice the details of this life that used to slip through my awareness and be forgotten so quickly, always in pursuit of the next accomplishment. I want to be brave enough to witness the fear and heartbreak and tragedy of this world and keep combating it with love + art + hope + soul. 

I spent many years of my life feeling powerless, hiding shame, numbing + dissociating, afraid to show up fully. Saying yes when my soul said no. Caring more about being accepted than being myself. Ignoring my gut instincts and suppressing my wholeness to make others feel safe in theirs. Now I am experiencing what it is to be one with myself, not dividing myself into parts to fit in. 

If I could tell my younger self anything it would be: stop trying to please, prove, perform, and pretend. Be shamelessly true to yourself and you’ll find your power. 

At 46, I am reclaiming my purity of spirit and the power of my authenticity. Building a lifestyle that sings my values. Channeling gratitude, gratitude, gratitude. There’s no time to waste, and I’m not saying that in a scarcity way, but in a focused and purpose-filled way. I’m done giving energy to regret and shame. The only direction is onward.

Right now, the words of @xavier.dagba having been a light in dark times: 

“In a divided world, we need more bridges.
Wherever you can, be one.
Start within yourself.
Bridge your inner divide.
Reconcile with the parts you like the least.
Let them enter your heart again.
That’s how you heal your Self.
That’s how we heal the world.”

Here are a few that often keep us stuck:

〰️ The way things have always been done is the way we should always do them

〰️ What leads to happiness or success for someone else will lead to the same for us

〰️ Past mistakes are an indication of future results
What doesn’t come naturally can’t be learned 

〰️ People don’t want to help us and will take advantage of our vulnerability if we ask for help

〰️ Discomfort is always bad and familiarity is always good

〰️ Awareness is enough and we don’t have to act on what we know to realize the benefits

〰️ We’ll feel more fulfillment from the results than the process

〰️ We can’t take action if we don’t have all the answers

What else would you add to this list from your personal experience? What conclusions have you jumped to in order to talk yourself out of living your dreams and desires?

Creative courage is all about questioning your assumptions and showing yourself what’s possible when you take inspired action in spite of fear and uncertainty. Life is full of choice moments, big and small, and when you realize that your choices are shaping your life, you can ask yourself what am I saying Yes to and what  am I saying No to with my actions. 

For example:  When I “don’t feel like” taking my daily walk, I’m saying Yes to achy joints, lower energy, and moodiness. Likewise, I’m saying No to better mental health, better circulation, and a healthier heart. 

When I avoid the operational aspects of my business, I’m saying Yes to stress, confusion, and survival mode. I’m also saying No to ease, creative expansion, and prosperity. 

Observe your patterns for a week (without judgment) and ask yourself what you’re saying Yes to and what you’re saying No to, particularly in areas where you are seeking change or growth. Be as specific as possible so you can feel the emotional impact of your choices. Are your actions aligning with what you say you want? Who you want to be? If not, you can get to the root of it and be honest with yourself and ask yourself why. Your habitual actions are not necessarily who you are, often we having coping mechanisms and emotional wounds that shape our actions and we assume we can’t change. But you CAN learn how to align your actions with your values and desires. 

When it comes to your creative life, why are your actions saying Yes to, and what are they saying No to? 

Our free first Friday workshop this week will include prompts and readings from the theme Voice and Vision, as we’ll be reflecting on 2023 and setting intentions for 2024. All registrants will receive a writing guide with self-discovery and creative writing exercises to help them  imagine how they want to use their voices and visions in the new year.

You can RSVP through the link in my bio.

“I understood that I was inventing myself, and that I was doing this more in the way of a painter than in the way of a scientist. I could not count on precision or calculation; I could only count on intuition.” Jamaica Kincaid

I’m thrilled to share this news, and I’m even more thrilled to share the nuance of what this represents to me. I thought my first book deal would be this huge defining moment that would make me feel worthy. I have so much compassion for the version of me that thought I needed this validation to feel official. The version of me that thought I needed to be chosen and given permission. I love her, and I needed her. Because she showed me where long-lasting purpose and motivation truly come from.

She wanted to prove herself, and she discovered that this desire was actually an invitation to find a longer lasting reward.

All my life, I got my sense of self-worth from being a good girl who accomplished things: scholarships, internships, promotions, etc. As a child, there wasn’t much I could control in my life, but achievement brought a feeling of security. It shaped me and how I would come to seek love—and feel worthy of it—for years to come. 

Back in 2013, when I changed careers to focus on writing, I hadn’t yet learned what achievement means to me and why. I went from corporate America to creative entrepreneurship still wanting to be accepted by successful people to feel loved. Ultimately I would have to bring this subconscious need out of the shadows and transform it because it was stifling my creativity.

Achievement is still important to me, but I embrace it with a deeper understanding. On its own it’s an addiction, but I can partner it with my other values like authenticity and creative expression to channel it towards a purpose bigger than me. Working together, these values turn a need for validation into a drive for connection.

So I’m looking at this book as an opportunity for more of that connection. I hope it will foster it by inspiring people to think and live creatively, no matter what they’re facing. 

Huge thanks to the @writingthelayers  @permissiontowrite @thewriterscenter communities for the inspiration, guidance + support.✨

How do I bridge the disconnect between my creative callings and my actions? This is an important question to explore when you are struggling with procrastination, perfection, and resistance around your creative urges.

Resistance occurs when our hearts, minds, and bodies are not in alignment with each other. Maybe your heart says yes, but your mind says no. Maybe your mind is full of ideas, but your body freezes up when it’s time to express them. It’s self-reflection, honesty, and mindfulness that reveals these inner conflicts. Once you pull these inner conflicts out of the shadows you can find clarity. From that clarity you can build the courage and confidence to make new choices. New choices change your life and allow you to expand into fuller expression. 

Creative courage requires a changing of the heart, an opening of the mind, and the physical embodiment of your values. If you are working on your creative courage, I invite you to save the questions in the carousel for your next journaling session and use writing as a tool to explore your contradictions.

I’ve always felt like a late bloomer, and it has a lot to do with how long it took me to stop living my life to fit in, measure up, and please other people. 

I don’t know who needs to hear this, but what you don’t know, you can learn. What makes you uncomfortable to reveal about yourself can be overcome. You are capable. You are worthy. You’re not too old. You’re not too late. You’re not too broken. You can learn new things, express yourself in new ways, and find new possibilities for your life.

What I love most about my work now is showing people how pursuing their creative callings improves their overall quality of life. When I left my ‘secure’ corporate job 10 years ago, I wanted to find a creative livelihood to replace it that would be better for my mental health. What I found was courage, audacity, and vision that I’d struggled to find when I was living according to other people’s expectations. An adventure that changed my whole outlook on what’s possible if you let your life become a reflection of who you really really are. 

Creative courage affects your whole life. How you show up at work, in your relationships, in your self-care and community-care, your mental and physical health - everything. As you pursue your creative callings, you address your fears, insecurities + bad habits so you can find the clarity to make authentic decisions for your life. 

In the Creative Courage Writing Intensive, we take this journey together through self-reflection, writing + storytelling. This is for those who value creative expression, but struggle to overcome things like doubt, self-consciousness +uncertainty. Through a combination of guided self-study, group coaching, and community wisdom, participants come away with both reclaimed stories + strategic knowledge that set them up for long-term creative growth.

Courage requires change + change requires courage. My life looks so different now because I realized that I would always feel restless and unfulfilled unless I surrendered to change. I had to let some things go to make room for who I wanted to become. 

Creative Courage starts in January. You can learn more through the link in my bio.✨

A story about progress that I thought was failure: In 2019, I started a writing group called the All the Many Layers Writing Circle. I’d been writing + facilitating workshops for over five years, and I wanted to get experience in long-term group coaching. I kept it open for less than a year. 

The decision to end the group came from an exciting opportunity. I was commissioned to author a book on self-care, the Self-Care Check-in Guided Journal. I had never worked with a publisher before, and I was overwhelmed and intimidated at the speedy turnaround time they were requesting. I thought, okay, it’s time for me to focus on my writing for a while.

So I closed the group. I was low-key embarrassed because it felt like a failure, but I was honest with my community about why I was doing it. I was like, look y’all, I have a vision and to bring it to life I’m going to have to learn how to manage my time + energy, regulate my nervous system, and develop processes and systems so I can handle it all. I’m gonna step away and go figure it out and when the time is right, I’m going to share everything I learn.

I would end up writing another journal for that publisher, so I spent 2020-22 writing, promoting, facilitating, and speaking, thanks to the opportunities that those books brought my way. By late 2022, I was ready to start another writing group. 

What was the difference? 

When I closed the first writing group, I didn’t have a reliable creative process + I didn’t have boundaries. I needed help with my blindspots + learning curves. I needed to study my creative process like a scientist studying an experiment. I researched, tested, observed, and analyzed. 

I focused on expanding my capacity to take on more responsibility in a physically, mentally, emotionally + spiritually healthy way. All the factors in the carousel above were necessary to set me up for the progress that was coming. 

What happens when you redefine failure and release old identities that are holding you back from your creative potential? I’ll share more in part two.

(part two) In part one I was talking about signs of progress that we often think are signs of failure. Part two is about what happens when you redefine failure and release old identities that are holding you back from your creative potential.

I acknowledged all these identities while I took a step back and studied my process. I started a new coaching program in 2022 ready to step into full ownership of my passions and gifts. In 2023, I spent the year growing and pouring into that community. I finished my book proposal, found an agent, and sold my book to a publisher. In 2024, I’m finishing the book and continuing to honor and study and teach the creative process. I’m sharing this two-part story to show the difference between doing the mindset work and not doing it, having a reliable process and not having one. 

To progress we have to release versions of ourselves that we outgrow. We have to release the mindsets that once protected us and helped us survive. It’s not easy to let go of what once made you feel safe, and we get stuck there sometimes, between who we were and who we are becoming. 

When it comes to our creative goals and callings, often our goals, dreams, and plans are abandoned when we don’t develop the mindsets and habits that give us the capacity to carry them out. 

After understanding that I would need a reliable creative process to expand my creative life and business in a physically, mentally, emotionally + spiritually healthy way…I studied my creative process like a scientist studying an experiment. I coach creatives through this transformative self-study in The Creative Courage Writing Intensive which starts on January 11. Link in bio to learn more.

What identities are you releasing in 2024 and what are you letting in? What’s your plan for doing the work?

It’s amazing the shift that happens when you realize that no matter what you’ve been through, your story can be a source of strength instead of weakness.

Maybe growing up you were taught that it’s not safe to tell your story. You don’t reveal who you really are or what you’re going through. Not at home. Not at work. Everywhere you look, there’s judgment. For many of us, this means we ended up speaking our truths nowhere. The fear of disapproval and/or punishment held our tongues well into adulthood. 

I can understand the need for discernment in how we share our stories, but with a creative lens, there are positive and transformative ways of expressing our lived experiences. So that we can break cycles. So we can advocate for the well-being of ourselves and others. So we can heal, grow, serve, teach, and minister. We can start by writing our stories down, practicing self-honesty and acceptance with ourselves. 

Before you can quiet the inner critic that gets in the way of your creative voice, you need to get super clear on why you are writing. What do you hope to get out of it? What are your intentions? You can move beyond fear by choosing intentions that speak to your heart, not your ego, that spark your imagination and give you a feeling of purpose. The storyteller types above can help you connect to what matters to you on that deeper level, so when doubt comes along you have something firm to hold onto. 

You need compelling reasons to work through the fear, you know? You’re baring your soul for what reason? You’re making time for this for what result? What do you expect to gain as you venture outside of your comfort zone? Why is it worth it?

What if we showed up in our writing and creative work with the audacity to be too much? The majority of writers I work with are creatively blocked by a fear of being vulnerable and being perceived as “too much”. 

Can you relate? 

If we’re afraid of this in our personal and professional lives, it will most definitely show up in our creative lives. We have to unlearn the thoughts and habits and labels that block us from showing up boldly in our expression. 

On Substack I share reflections on writing, vulnerability, and creative courage. If you’re in the practice of writing about your life (or want to be) I share stories and insights from my creative journey, as well as tools for your own practice. Whether you write privately or publicly, you’ll find insights on writing to heal, grow, and connect. 

My coaching clients and paid subscribers receive story work exercises every Sunday night, each one to support you in using creative thinking to reclaim your story and discover new visions for your life.

This is what my book-in-progress is all about. Looking at your life experiences as creative material that you have the power to shape. To follow me on Substack, explore free resources, and more, go to the link in my bio. ✨

Writing does not have to be hard.

Get curious about why it feels difficult. Are you trying to prove something? Impress someone? 
Instead, use writing as a practice in vulnerability and self-discovery. Self-ownership. 

As I’m writing the first draft of my current book, I’m not thinking about how many copies it will sell. I’m thinking about how much love and vulnerability I can pour into it. 

Im not thinking about literary devices and wordplay right now, I’m writing my truths and fears and obsessions and dreams and passions in the simplest and most honest and thorough way I can. I’m pouring it out so I can have a mound of clay to work with and gradually, through many drafts, mold into a piece of art. 

It’s a process. If you dream of writing projects but can’t get past insecurities about your writing, focus on understanding the process. Maybe your urge to write is really about an urge for an outlet where you can be vulnerable. Follow that urge.

When you’re unsure of your voice and purpose and audience as a writer, look for clues in the writing you love. Let the writers who inspire you show you what’s possible. 

Think about the writers whose work feels like an invitation to you. Pay attention to that. 

It’s not about comparing yourself or imitating, it’s about recognizing a kindred spirit, someone whose language speaks uniquely to you, whose language AWAKENS something in you.

And allow yourself to enter into a call and response with them in your writing. Follow that path of discovery and see what it pulls out of you and just observe how your voice evolves and what shape your writing takes. 

Don’t wait to get started until you fully understand who you are and what you’re doing with your writing, it doesn’t work that way. You start with an urge, you follow it, and you figure it out as you go.

So much love to @iamsusanltaylor for the inspiration. ✨

What you don’t know, you can learn.

What you’re not good at, you can practice. 

Do you believe that what you want is too hard, impossible, or out of reach because of your limitations? Do you believe that if it’s not easy right away, it’s not meant for you?

What if the true reward is gaining a deeper understanding of how you move through challenges and transcend limitations? What if the true reward is showing yourself that your limiting beliefs aren’t true?

Living a creative life requires self-trust, humility, and the willingness to be a beginner. It also requires a faith that your callings are yours for a reason. 

If you focus on taking one step at a time, keeping your bigger vision in mind, you will build courage, confidence, and clarity as you move through obstacles. Taking action, even small baby steps, provides you with information that reveals unexpected insights and demystifies the process. 

Instead of asking yourself, ‘What’s wrong with me?’ start asking yourself ‘What do I need? Who can help me? How can I look at this differently? What is this obstacle trying to teach me?’

It’s not a matter of if you can do it, it’s a matter of figuring out what works for you.

Once I stopped beating myself up and arguing for my limitations, I got curious about what I could do without this disadvantaged narrative that was keeping me stuck. 

Specifically in my writing journey, this meant letting go of rules and “should’s”, asking for help, admitting what I didn’t know, finding people to learn with, experimenting over and over, taking risks based on the idea that I will either win or I will grow.

In my writing group, the Inner Story Writing Circle, we approach our writing goals from the inside out, doing the inner work that cultivates a healthy creative mindset, so the writers can get unstuck and get free to explore the possibilities that their writing journey has to offer. 

To learn more about it, visit www.allthemanylayers.com/inner-story-coaching or link in bio.

I think this was Atlantic City, NJ circa 1982ish. Using old photos is an excellent way to bring memories to life and start writing. My writing journey started with a desire to heal and relocate the voice that this little girl lost. To break free from the silence that I thought was protecting her. 
.
The experiences that hurt us, imprinted on us, planted seeds of shame or guilt or inadequacy or whatever — they were made more lethal when we were not given safe spaces to talk about them and acknowledge that they happened.
.
If you feel called to write or tell your story, and you don’t know where to begin, look at your life and make a list of key memories that have shaped you. Once you have that list, use the memories as writing prompts and write the stories you never told yourself. Write what you need to say, and what you need to hear. Start there.
.
I’m facilitating a two-day workshop through @thewriterscenter online this Sunday and next. Journaling Techniques for Writing Memories is about the pursuit of insight through writing personal memories. Whether you currently keep a journal or want to start journaling to nurture a consistent writing practice, in this two-day workshop you will learn journaling techniques that help you recall significant memories and explore the meaning behind those experiences. 

We will explore how a memoir writer’s journal differs from a regular journal, how to get your memoir journal started, and how to work with your captured memories to create a single storyline. You will have the opportunity to share a draft of one of your stories in a safe creative space. You can learn more and register through the link in my bio by clicking on Offerings and Workshops.
